citation.article-title: Haloglycomyces albus gen. nov., sp. nov., a halophilic, filamentous actinomycete of the family Glycomycetaceae
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Haloglycomyces albus sp. nov.
Haloglycomyces albus (al′bus. L. masc. adj. albus white, referring to the white aerial mycelium).
Morphological, chemotaxonomic and general characteristics are as given above for the genus.
Substrate mycelium is yellow–white to deep orange–yellow on tested media.
White aerial hyphae are produced on ISP2, ISP4, nutrient agar and Czapek's agar plates with 10 % NaCl.
Temperature and pH ranges for growth are 15–40 °C and pH 5.0–9.0, with optima at 37 °C and pH 7.0–7.5.
No growth at 10 or 45 °C or above pH 9.0.
Growth occurs in the presence of 3–18 % NaCl, but not below 3 % NaCl; optimal concentration 8–12 % NaCl.

Utilizes cellobiose, glucose, maltose, mannitol, mannose, rhamnose and sorbitol as sole carbon sources, but not d-arabinose, dextrin, fructose, galactose, glycerol, inositol, lactose, melibiose, raffinose, ribose, xylitol or xylose.
Positive for gelatin hydrolysis, starch hydrolysis, milk coagulation and peptonization, but negative for urease, cellulose hydrolysis, production of H2S and nitrate reduction.
The type strain, YIM 92370T (=DSM 45210T=KCTC 19481T), was isolated from a soil sample from a hypersaline habitat in Xinjiang Province, north-west China.
